newsitem.title: USA: Cincinnati Bell says won't split company.
newsitem.headline: Cincinnati Bell says won't split company.

text.p: Cincinnati Bell Inc reiterated on Friday that it did not plan to split up the company at the present time, nor did it anticipate making a major acquisition or being acquired.
A Business Week article quoted a money manager as saying she believed Cincinnati Bell was an attractive takeover candidate and that its management might be mulling a break-up of the company.
Cincinnati Bell Chief Executive Officer John LaMacchia addressed those issues in an interview with Reuters published last week.

Asked if the company might split or spin off its fast-growing CBIS billing and MATRIXX Marketing units or its local telephone company, Cincinnati Bell Telephone, La Macchia told Reuters, "Not at the present time."

Asked about acquisitions, he said while the company is always on the lookout for small, strategic acquisitions, "beyond that, we're not aiming at any big targets, and no big targets are aiming at us as far as we know."
He also said Cincinnati Bell "can't quibble" with analysts' 1996 earnings estimates of $2.39-$2.40 a share, versus $1.72 excluding special charges in 1995.
A spokesman said Friday that the company has not changed its views since the interview.

LaMacchia said that the local phone company, like similar companies, faces uncertainties about competition and deregulation. In addition, previously reported renogotiation continues of a major contract the local phone company, which serves the Cincinnati area, has with AT&T Corp.
But, LaMacchia said, the parent company is not at present considering splitting or spinning off any units.

"Part of the reason is that a lot of the expertise that CBIS and MATRIXX bring to the communications industry comes out of their association with (Cincinnati Bell Telephone)," said LaMacchia, who is also president.

He said CBIS, which generates bills and provides customer care services for cellular phone companies and other clients, accounts for about $450 million in revenues, and MATRIXX, which handles telemarketing calls, mainly incoming, for other companies, accounts for about $320 million.
